titles.title: Agreeing
titles.info: You can say that you support what somebody has said in a number of ways.

titles.title: Asking for opinions
titles.info: When you need to find out what somebody thinks or you want to involve others in a conversation, you can ask for opinions.

titles.title: Conceding a point
titles.info: When you want to show that somebody has convinced you with their argument, at least partially, you can concede.

titles.title: Dealing with questions
titles.info: If you are talking to a group of people, you need to be able to deal with the questions that people ask.

titles.title: Disagreeing
titles.info: There are various polite ways of saying that you think something somebody has said is wrong.

titles.title: Expressing preferences
titles.info: When you are asked to make a choice, you can express preferences in various ways.

titles.title: Giving reasons
titles.info: You can explain and justify your choices and decisions in a number of ways.

titles.title: Interrupting somebody
titles.info: If you need to say something when somebody else is speaking or to stop somebody in a group talking too much, there are a various ways of interrupting politely.

titles.title: Asking for clarification
titles.info: When you are given some information or asked to do something, you can check that you have understood correctly in various ways.

titles.title: Correcting yourself
titles.info: When you say something that was not quite what you intended, you can correct yourself in various ways.

titles.title: Expressing certainty
titles.info: When you are stating what has happened or is going to happen, there are various ways of saying how certain or uncertain you are.

titles.title: Expressing ignorance
titles.info: There are different ways of telling people that you haven't got the information they're asking for.

titles.title: Expressing likelihood
titles.info: When you are talking about possible situations, you can express how likely you think they are.

titles.title: Speculating
titles.info: There are various ways of giving your opinion when you don't know all the details or facts about something.

titles.title: Apologizing
titles.info: When you have caused a problem for somebody, you can make polite apologies in various ways.

titles.title: Congratulating somebody
titles.info: When somebody tells you some good news about their family, or what they have done, you can congratulate them.

titles.title: Expressing sympathy
titles.info: If someone is ill, or something bad has happened to them, you can express that you are sorry.

titles.title: Making complaints
titles.info: When something you buy is of poor quality or the standard of service you receive is not good enough, you can express your dissatisfaction in various ways.

titles.title: Thanking somebody
titles.info: When someone gives you something, or does something for you, there are different ways of saying more than just a brief 'thank you'.

titles.title: Wishing somebody luck
titles.info: If someone is going to do something difficult, you can wish them luck.

titles.title: Ending conversations
titles.info: When you stop talking to somebody, you can end the conversation in a number of ways.

titles.title: Introducing somebody
titles.info: There are different ways of introducing people to one another, depending on how formal the situation is.

titles.title: Inviting somebody to something
titles.info: You can make and respond to invitations in a number of ways.

titles.title: Leaving phone messages
titles.info: If you phone somebody who is not able to take your call, you may need to leave a message.

titles.title: Opening conversations
titles.info: When speaking to someone for the first time, you will need to know some possible ways of starting a conversation. When talking in front of a group of people, you may also want to know how to get their attention.

titles.title: Wrapping up discussions
titles.info: In a formal meeting or conference, you may have to bring the session to a close. There are some polite ways to get people to stop speaking.

titles.title: Asking about obligation
titles.info: When you are unsure about what is expected of you in a situation, you can ask about obligations.

titles.title: Asking for permission
titles.info: If you need to ask for permission or a favour, you are more likely to get what you want if you can ask for it politely.

titles.title: Forbidding something
titles.info: There are different polite ways of asking somebody not to do something.

titles.title: Giving orders
titles.info: There are various ways of telling somebody to do something politely.

titles.title: Making requests
titles.info: Whether you are in shops or restaurants or in somebody's home, you can use polite questions to get what you want.

titles.title: Asking for help
titles.info: If you need help, people are more likely to react favourably if you ask politely.

titles.title: Asking for information
titles.info: When you want to find something out, it sounds more polite if you can phrase your questions in an indirect way.

titles.title: Giving somebody advice
titles.info: There are a various tactful ways of telling somebody what you think they should do.

titles.title: Making recommendations
titles.info: When you need help making a choice, you can ask somebody to give you their view.

titles.title: Making suggestions
titles.info: When you are asked to make suggestions, there are various ways of putting forward your ideas.

titles.title: Offering help
titles.info: There are a various ways of offering and accepting help.

titles.title: Offering somebody something
titles.info: Particularly when you are the host, you may want to make polite offers to your guests.

titles.title: Warning somebody of danger
titles.info: You may need to tell someone that they are in danger or advise them not to do something dangerous.
